newsitem.title: GERMANY: Tietmeyer says currencies better suit fundamentals.
newsitem.headline: Tietmeyer says currencies better suit fundamentals.

text.p: Bundesbank President Hans Tietmeyer said on Thursday that current foreign exchange rate levels were more in line with fundamentals on both sides of the Atlantic.
In a speech to a Goldman Sachs conference in Frankfurt, Tietmeyer said the recent exchange rate corrections should not be seen signalling the future single currency would be weak.
"As the finance ministers and central bank governors of the G7 countries recently affirmed in Berlin, what we have seen so far is a correction of the exaggerated moves seen in past years," he said.
Tietmeyer says currencies better suit fundamentals
A text of the speech was released in advance of delivery.
Tietmeyer said that Germany remained interested in a stable mark and a stable euro and that he hoped this view was shared by other European Union nations.

"We in Germany are interested in the mark remaining a stable currency and in the euro being a comparably stable and strong currency," he said. "I hope that this is also seen this way in other European countries."
He added that the stability and credibility of the single currency would play an important role in ensuring a smooth transfer from national currencies to the euro.
"Only then will the transition from national currencies to the euro be possible without (market) distortions," he said.
Tietmeyer said that the decision on which countries could take part in the euro should be made in the early part of 1998, no earlier and no later.
He added that any "short-sighted decisions" on fiscal policy, or any softening of the Maastricht entry criteria would set a wrong signal.
